review.title: Extending Gossip Algorithms to Distributed Estimation of U-statistics
review.abstract: Efficient and robust algorithms for decentralized estimation in networks are essential to many distributed systems. Whereas distributed estimation of sample mean statistics has been the subject of a good deal of attention, computation of $U$-statistics, relying on more expensive averaging over pairs of observations, is a less investigated area. Yet, such data functionals are essential to describe global properties of a statistical population, with important examples including Area Under the Curve, empirical variance, Gini mean difference and within-cluster point scatter. This paper proposes new synchronous and asynchronous randomized gossip algorithms which simultaneously propagate data across the network and maintain local estimates of the $U$-statistic of interest. We establish convergence rate bounds of $O(1/t)$ and $O(\log t / t)$ for the synchronous and asynchronous cases respectively, where $t$ is the number of iterations, with explicit data and network dependent terms. Beyond favorable comparisons in terms of rate analysis, numerical experiments provide empirical evidence the proposed algorithms surpasses the previously introduced approach.

metadata.title: Extending Gossip Algorithms to Distributed Estimation of U -Statistics

sections.heading: 3 Related Work
sections.text: Gossip algorithms have been extensively studied in the context of decentralized averaging in networks, where the goal is to calculate the average of n real numbers (X = R). Of particular interest to us is the work of [2], which uses a randomized gossip algorithm to calculate the empirical mean (4) in a context where nodes wake up asynchronously and simply traverse their local estimate with that of a randomly selected neighbor. Communication probabilities are given by a stochastic matrix P in which Pij is the probability that a node i selects neighbor j to a given iteration.

sections.heading: 4.2 Asynchronous Setting
sections.text: In this section, we will override the global clock assumption and propose a complete asynchronous algorithm assumption in which each node has a local clock, as in the synchronous setting (you can refer to more details on clock modeling), but in a given iteration step, it is only about the selected pair of nodes. Therefore, the nodes must maintain an estimate of the current iteration number to ensure an unbiased estimate of the clock modeling (H).

sections.heading: 5 Experiments
sections.text: In this section we present two applications on real data sets: the decentralized estimation of the area below the ROC curve (AUC) and the point catters within the cluster. We compare the performance of our algorithms with that of U2 gossip [18] - see additional material for additional comparisons to some basic methods. We run our simulations on the three types of networks described below (corresponding values of 1-2 (2) are shown in Table 1. • Complete graph: This is the case where all nodes are connected to each other. It is the ideal situation within our framework, since each pair of nodes can communicate directly.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We have introduced new synchronous and asynchronous randomised gossip algorithms to calculate statistics that depend on observation pairs (U statistics). We have the convergence rate in5This dataset is available at http: / / mldata.org / repository / data / viewslug / svmguide3 / 6This dataset is available at https: / / archive.ics.uci.edu / ml / datasets / Wineboth settings, and numerical experiments confirm the practical interest of the proposed algorithms. In future work, we plan to investigate whether adaptive communication programs (such as those of [7, 14]) can be used to accelerate our algorithms. Our contribution could also be used as a building block for decentralised optimization of U statistics, extending the approaches of [8, 17] for example.

sections.heading: D U2-gossip Algorithm
sections.text: U2-gossip [18] is an alternative approach for calculating U statistics. = > In this algorithm, each node stores two additional observations, which are updated by means of independent random walks. − These two additional observations are used for estimating U statistics - see algorithm 4 for details. − n This algorithm has a convergence rate of O (1 / t), as stated in Theorem 4.Let k [n]. − n At the end of the iteration t = 1, the additional observations have not yet been interchanged, so the expected estimator E [Zk] is simply updated as follows: E [Zk (1) = E [Zk (0)] > kHek.Then, at the end of the iteration, auxiliary observations are randomly swapped.

sections.heading: E Comparison to Baseline Methods
sections.text: In this section, we will use the scatter problem presented within the cluster, which is examined in section 5, to compare our algorithms with two - more naive - baseline methods described below. This baseline uses the same communication scheme as GoSta-async (algorithm 2) to flood the observations across the network, but we assume that each node has enough memory to store all the observations it receives. At each iteration, each selected node selects a random observation from among those it currently holds, and sends it to the other (tagged with the node it originally owned) to avoid storing duplicates. Local estimates are calculated using the observations available on each node (the middle step is removed).Figure 4 shows the evolution over time of the average relative error and the associated standard deviations over the nodes for these baseline nodes, the baseline nodes, and the deviations between the nodes.

referenceMentions.context: Gossip algorithms [20, 19, 6], where each node exchanges information with at most one of its neighbors at a time, have emerged as a simple yet powerful technique for distributed computation in such settings.

Gossip algorithms [20, 19, 6], where each node exchanges information with at most one of its neighbors at a time, have emerged as a simple yet powerful technique for distributed computation in such settings.

Given a data observation on each node, gossip algorithms can be used to compute averages or sums of functions of the data that are separable across observations (see for example [11, 2, 16, 12, 10] and references therein).

Unfortunately, these algorithms cannot be used to efficiently compute quantities that take the form of an average over pairs of observations, also known as U -statistics [13].

These convergence bounds feature datadependent terms that reflect the hardness of the estimation problem, and network-dependent terms related to the spectral gap of the network graph [4], showing that our algorithms are faster on wellconnected networks.
Our results largely improve upon those presented in [18]: in particular, we achieve faster convergence together with lower memory and communication costs.

The first one is the within-cluster point scatter [5], which measures the clustering quality of a partition We point out that the usual definition of U -statistic differs slightly from (1) by a factor of n/(n− 1).

Of particular interest to us is the work of [2], which introduces a randomized gossip algorithm for computing the empirical mean (4) in a context where nodes wake up asynchronously and simply average their local estimate with that of a randomly chosen neighbor.

As long as the network graph is connected and non-bipartite, the local estimates converge to (4) at a rate O(e−ct) where the constant c can be tied to the spectral gap of the network graph [4], showing faster convergence for well-connected networks.

metadata.abstractText: Efficient and robust algorithms for decentralized estimation in networks are essential to many distributed systems. Whereas distributed estimation of sample mean statistics has been the subject of a good deal of attention, computation of U statistics, relying on more expensive averaging over pairs of observations, is a less investigated area. Yet, such data functionals are essential to describe global properties of a statistical population, with important examples including Area Under the Curve, empirical variance, Gini mean difference and within-cluster point scatter. This paper proposes new synchronous and asynchronous randomized gossip algorithms which simultaneously propagate data across the network and maintain local estimates of the U -statistic of interest. We establish convergence rate bounds of O(1/t) and O(log t/t) for the synchronous and asynchronous cases respectively, where t is the number of iterations, with explicit data and network dependent terms. Beyond favorable comparisons in terms of rate analysis, numerical experiments provide empirical evidence the proposed algorithms surpasses the previously introduced approach.
